question: It is a lie. I caught him stealing ours. The lowlife jabbers some more. The Interrogator debates.
answer: No!... I took the bread.

question: That's not true.
answer: They're not interested in truth. You are too weak, Peter. You would not live through it. The Interrogator stares into Robin's eyes. And this is English courage. He hurls his holders aside. Swings upward, driving his fast into the executioner's throat. Grabs the sword. Slash. His thongs melt like butter. A jailer leaps at him. Steaming, the scimitar slices into the man's chest. Despite his bindings, Peter wrestles the Interrogator. Knife pressed to his throat, Peter is forced against the furnace. At the last second, he flips the man into the fire. Screaming.

question: That's for five years of hell.
answer: You speak English?

question: What I would give for an English sword. This is a pruning hook. A guard swings at him with a giant axe. Robin slashes... shears the axe handle in two. Hmm! Not bad. He runs the man through. Peter loses his sword. His opponent moves in for the kill... Peter grabs tongs from the fire and smolders his opponent with a backhand. Commotion outside. RAISED VOICES and RUNNING FEET.
answer: Free me and I will show you a way out.

question: Why should we trust you?
answer: If you don't, you are dead men.

question: Come now! Do not fail your friend. Make his sacrifice an act of honor. They vanish into the night. Fighting like a man pos- sessed, Peter is swallowed in a sea of enemy soldiers.
answer: Farewell, friend. God speed you on your way.

question: Our way is together. With the speed of Allah. He grins. This strange man has a sense of humor.
answer: I go to England.

question: Then I go to England.
answer: England? Why?

question: You saved my life. I must stay with you until I save yours.
answer: Go your own way. I relieve you of your obligation.

question: Only Allah can do that.
answer: And if I don't want you?

question: You have no choice... unless you think you can kill me. He grins broadly. Offers his hand. My name is Aslan. Resigned, Robin takes the proferred hand.
answer: Robin of Locksley. You know a short route to England, Aslan? CUT TO:

question: My Lord, please!
answer: It is alright, Duncan. You are Kenneth of Cowfall? The peasant falls to his knees.

question: They've taken my Gwen. My daughter.
answer: Who has taken her?

question: Good will overcome, Duncan. Trust in that. Duncan looks up. Crosses himself. Dark clouds race across the moon. CUT TO:
answer: They came this way, my Lord.

question: Onward then. What is this place?
answer: Nearby the Gregor Caves. Locksley reacts -- a hint of fear. They move on... Ahead, the hillside glows, rimmed in eerie light. Strange primitive CHANTS, wafted on the wind. Locksley ties his nervous horse to a tree. Parting undergrowth, Kenneth creeps forward. Cries out. He's face to face with the maggot-eaten skull of a goat. Beyond it, a gruesome host of half-skinned human skulls, all arranged on stakes. Some male, others with rotting female tresses, staring eyelessly into the night. Kenneth turns to run... A hand grabs him.

question: Steady, man. They are to dissuade the faint of heart. Think of Gwen. From the crest of the rise, they peer down into the craggy valley. A cave opening, ablaze with flames leers at them like the mouth of hell. Before the cave, a circle of stones. A miniature Stonehenge. A medieval orgy. Men and women in masks and loose robes. Dancing. Drinking. Reveling. Pure carnality. Lord Locksley and Kenneth watch in horror. Faces ashen.
answer: Druids.

question: I trusted we were rid of such evil a century ago.
answer: Is it the devil?

question: If it is, I have some Christian steel that will test his hide. He draws his sword. A crucifix sculpted into the hilt. A girl is dragged from the cave. Kenneth buries his head. Gwen? Kenneth nods. The Demon shrieks, dervishing around GWEN, who is carried onto the central plinth stone. A pagan altar, the shape of an elephant's head with its trunk raised. A masked figure stands at the head of the altar. The high priest of the dark rite. The girl's body shudders as blood-red liquid is forced down her throat. The Demon's voice is husky and hideous. Gwen! Up, girl, up! Gwen shakes off her trance. The Demon launches itself at Locksley. Talons rip flesh from his face. With all his strength, Locksley hurls the creature down. In the name of God! His broadsword swings in a mighty arc. Slices across the gargoyle's skull. Clean through half the face... Impossibly, the demon rolls back to its feet. Nottingham! The SHERIFF OF NOTTINGHAM. Powerful build, black beard, cruel intensity in every feature.
answer: You are an unwelcome surprise, Locksley.

question: The King shall hear of this, Nottingham.
answer: I think not. Locksley is surrounded. One by one the men reveal their faces. Locksley backs up in shock, recognizing them. One day all England will worship with us.

question: Home. Thank you, Lord. Aslan steps from the boat, sniffing the air. The French sailors keep their distance from him. Robin takes his hand. My friend, you have escorted me home. I beg you to free yourself of your vow. Return with the boat. I know how heavy your heart must be, this far from your family and native land...
answer: Because I love them so dearly, I cannot dishonor them. A sailor creeps up behind Aslan, club in hand.

question: I thought you'd say that. He nods to the sailor, who swings the club down. The Saracen sidesteps, grabs the man's arm and flips him into the surf. He turns a cold stare on Robin.
answer: No man controls my destiny. Especially not one who attacks downwind and stinks of garlic. Robin laughs. The Saracen remains intense. If our positions were reversed, I would have done the same. Only I would have succeeded. He smiles broadly. Robin claps him on the shoulder.

question: Where is your mate? The man they call Little.
answer: He died last winter.

question: Is that so? We hear he is very much alive. Hiding out in the forest. He probably ran away to escape your scolding tongue. The soldiers join in his laughter. Incensed, Fanny pounds her fist on his legs. Gisborne kicks her down.
answer: Norman swine! A BOY of 12 springs from nowhere, thrusting a hay fork at Gisborne's throat. No, Wulf! Don't! 'Twill only make it worse. Wulf backs off. Nostrils flaring with repressed hate.

question: Why must you walk in back of me?
answer: In your land am I not the infidel? The unbeliever, the instrument of evil?

question: Our races have fought for a hundred years to prove that point.
answer: Then I trust it is safer to appear as your slave than as your equal.

question: For an 'infidel' you have uncommon clarity of thinking. Yet you refuse to tell me about your home and family.
answer: Those are my burdens.

question: You speak my language. You have the diplomacy and honor code of a nobleman. I ask again, why were you to be executed? The Saracen maintains a moody silence. So, I must continue with my guesswork. You are highborn? Probably... You fell from favor... Clearly... Why? You broke the law? You were a rival for power? ... A woman? By the Lord, that's it! Aslan is silent, but Robin knows he's right. They say there are Arab women of such beauty that they can possess a man's mind, that he would be willing to die for them. Is that not so? Ignoring him, the Saracen stops. Examines the darkening sky.
answer: It is close to sunset.

question: Your people must marry women chosen for them by others, right? No reply. Aslan unfolds a prayer rug. Who is she? The Mullah's daughter? ... Another man's wife?... That's it!
answer: Endless clouds. Is there no sun in your cursed country?

question: You dog! You painted old dog! What is her name?
answer: Which way is East?

question: Her name?
answer: East?

question: Her name?
answer: East?!!! Robin folds his arms. A standoff. Damn you!... Jasmina.

question: Ah, Jasmina! Is she beautiful?
answer: Which way is East?

question: That way. Aslan throws his rug on the ground. Kneels.
answer: Are you sure?

question: I would know blindfolded. I'm five miles from home... Was she worth it?
answer: Worth dying for. Robin stands smiling over him as Aslan begins his prayers... BAYING of HUNTING DOGS... In the distance, the boy Wulf runs toward them, ducks behind a tree and clubs the leading dog with a branch. The other hounds close in... panting with exhaustion, Wulf swings into the branches. A hound savages his leg. The soldiers surround the tree. The boy clambers precariously onto the highest branch... Robin surrep- titiously steals a crossbow from one of the soldiers' horses.

question: You're not playing by the rules, boy. Deer don't climb trees... Perhaps he thinks he's a game bird. Shall we teach him to fly? Cut it down! The soldiers hack at the trunk. The tree quivers.
answer: Hold!... I am curious as to what manner of creature is so fearsome that it takes six men to attack it. Shrouded in his pilgrim's hooded cloak, he approaches them.

question: Stand back, stranger. This is no affair of yours.
answer: Have we treed the devil himself? Let me see... Ah ha! A small boy. A truly dangerous animal.

question: I advise you to move on, pilgrim. This is the Sheriff's land.
answer: Wrong. This is my land, and my tree. Therefore, whatever is in it also belongs to me.

question: I grow dangerously tired of your wit... Chop it down!
answer: The man who strikes that tree dies. He glances nervously at Aslan, who's still at his prayers. The men stop in mid-swing. More surprised than scared. Gisborne gestures to the largest of them.

question: Chop down the hooded fool.
answer: Perhaps we could discuss this.

question: Kill him!
answer: Aslan! It's time to redeem that vow.

question: Set the dogs on him!
answer: Aslan, get off your damn knees! I have four of them cornered. The Saracen remains head down. Or did we see him steal a glance? Gisborne signals his men to attack. A wave of flashing steel. I hope there's enough of me to satisfy you all. Backed up to a tree, he grabs a branch and kicks out. Two men fly back. He lunges at a third. His sword strikes flesh. Robin sidesteps and hurls the fourth onto a sharp tree stump. Gisborne thrusts. Robin reacts too slowly. Blood flows from his arm. His sword falls. Aslan!! Gisborne is on him, sword pressed to his back. Robin freezes.

question: Well, hooded stranger, allow me to know your name before I run you through. Robin of Locksley!
answer: On your knees, Gisborne. Pray. He obeys. Robin raises his sword.

question: Please, Locksley! No! Robin drives the point into Gisborne's rear. The man leaps.
answer: Now get off my land. And tell your cousin the Sheriff what happens to his scum when they pick on my people. Gisborne takes off, colliding with Aslan as he folds his rug. Reacts in shock at the sight of the strange Arab. Keeps running. You worthless savage! You travel ten thousand miles to save my life, then leave me to be butchered.

question: Now get off my land. And tell your cousin the Sheriff what happens to his scum when they pick on my people. Gisborne takes off, colliding with Aslan as he folds his rug. Reacts in shock at the sight of the strange Arab. Keeps running. You worthless savage! You travel ten thousand miles to save my life, then leave me to be butchered.
answer: I will fulfill my vow when I choose.

question: Which does not include prayer times, meal times, or any time I'm outnumbered six to one!!
answer: You whine like a mule. You are still alive.

question: Barely. Aslan examines Robin's wound. Dismissive.
answer: A flesh wound. Why did you let their leader go?

question: After six years of the stench of death, I have no stomach for needless blood on my hands. Wulf climbs cautiously from the tree. Have no fear, boy. The boy nervously eyes Robin and the Saracen, fingering a crucifix around his neck. Runs off into the woods.
answer: The conquering hero returns.

question: Ha! It was you he was scared of. Aslan's humor is infectious. Robin's anger relents. Come, my strange friend. Beyond that hill lies the prettiest little castle in all Christendom. Warm hearths, hot food, real beds.
answer: With feather pillows?

question: What has happened?
answer: They say they captured him worshipping with the Druids. He signed a confession before the Bishop of Hereford.

question: Did they have witnesses?
answer: Just one. Kenneth of Cowfall. The Bishop decreed all the Locksley lands forfeit.

question: Did you believe the charges?
answer: Not even when they took my eyes.

question: Who did this to you, Duncan?
answer: Guy of Gisborne. With the sheriff looking on. Robin holds the old retainer to his chest. Stares into the night in silent rage.

question: Away, fool. He shoves the Sentry aside.
answer: Who bade you cover up? He smashes his fist into his chair. She timidly uncovers. Cousin, I trust you justify your intrusion with news of profound value. His attention is riveted on a dark niche in the corner of the courtyard. UNEARTHLY SOUNDS emanate from the black- ness.

question: I met a hooded man today. He bade me warn you not to harm his people.
answer: His name?

question: Robin of Locksley.
answer: Ha! The prodigal son returns. He is a whelp. This girl could best him.

question: This whelp bested five of my men in the blink of an eye.
answer: Your men were probably drunk. Yet you survived, cousin? Heavy scorn. The sheriff pats Gisborne's hand like a child's. The voice from the darkness becomes a loud CHANT. A wrinkled, monkey-like figure dances INTO VIEW, wearing a necklace of human fingers. You might think she was a hundred years old, if not for her incredible agility. MORTIANNA.

question: You brought her here?
answer: Quiet! The crone's fingers dart into a bag. Emerge with a writhing, SQUEALING mass... a PIGLET. A knife flashes. Blood spurts into an ornate, sacred platter. The girl flinches in horror. Mortianna shakes the con- tents of a pouch across the bloody dish. Carved bone dice -- Runes. She rattles the platter. The rune symbols dance in trails of blood. Eyes vacant, mouth frothing, she hisses out her incoherent visions. Nottingham follows her every move. A connoisseur. What do you see?

question: Quiet! The crone's fingers dart into a bag. Emerge with a writhing, SQUEALING mass... a PIGLET. A knife flashes. Blood spurts into an ornate, sacred platter. The girl flinches in horror. Mortianna shakes the con- tents of a pouch across the bloody dish. Carved bone dice -- Runes. She rattles the platter. The rune symbols dance in trails of blood. Eyes vacant, mouth frothing, she hisses out her incoherent visions. Nottingham follows her every move. A connoisseur. What do you see?
answer: Change the seat of power.

question: London?
answer: Change it.

question: Move the capitol to Nottingham? Excellent. How?
answer: Ally with royal blood.

question: Put someone on the throne and rule through him? Who?
answer: That is not revealed. The idea takes shape in Nottingham's mind. Mounting intensity.

question: Ally with royal blood. What else do you see?
answer: Armies.

question: Whose?
answer: Yours. Men and weaponry in great numgers.

question: And victory?
answer: Much blood will be spilled.

question: Our last words in this world were spoken in anger. He called the Crusades a foolish quest, said it was vanity to force other men to our religion. He was right. Please forgive me, Father.
answer: He loved you till the end, young master. He never gave up hope of your return.

question: I failed him. I should have been here at his side.
answer: You must leave, head north to safety. Gisborne will surely seek revenge.

question: Leave me.
answer: I know what you're thinking. But one man can achieve nothing against so many. You would need an army.

question: Come, friend. He leads the old man away. CUT TO:
answer: He still stands vigil?

question: Like a rock. Duncan offers half the bread to the Saracen.
answer: A curse on the Saracens! Were it not for their ungodly ways, he would never have left. This would never have happened.

question: It surprises me that one who curses others so readily has lived so long.
answer: I do not recognize the style of your voice, friend. Are you Irish? A Cornishman?

question: Er... no.
answer: What manner of name is Aslan then?

question: A fine Saracen name.
answer: Lord, no! He chokes in shock. Spitting bread.

question: Lord, yes. But eat in peace. I take no offense. By the prophet! What is the man doing? Robin raises his dagger over his wrist. Aslan runs to him. Wait! Too late. Robin slashes the dagger across his palm. Rain and blood mingle. Streaming onto the grave.
answer: I swear by my own blood. I will not rest until I have restored my father's name. ... Or until I am dead. We make a fine army, do we not, Duncan? A blind man, an Arab, and a fool.

question: A fine, wet army. I have never witnessed a storm of such duration. When does summer come to this land?
answer: This is summer.

question: Then Allah truly is great.
answer: Why, pray?

question: No food, no shelter, and weather that would curse the end of the earth. We will all quickly be dead, and I shall be rid of my vow. They approach a stone wall, surrounding a thatched mansion.
answer: You despair too soon, Aslan. We shall find food and shelter here among friends.

question: What is this place?
answer: Peter's home. It is nearly seven years since we left here together.

question: Peter's home. It is nearly seven years since we left here together.
answer: No beggars! The hatch slams shut. Robin pounds again.

question: Open up! Tell the mistress of the house that Robin of Locksley is at her door.
answer: Her ladyship is not at home. She slams the hatch again. Robin jams in his hand.

question: Aagh! He shouts through the hatch, over his bruised fingers. Is the child Marian at home?
answer: Maybe she is. Maybe she isn't. Remove that hand. Robin refuses. She waits imperiously behind the locked door. Robin reluctantly withdraws his hand. Instantly the hatch slams.

question: Who are you? Dim lighting. Robin cannot make out who it is.
answer: I am Robin of Locksley.

question: You lie. Robin is dead.
answer: I may meet my maker soon from lack of sustenance. But for now I am real enough.

question: Step into the light. Turn around.
answer: By heaven, am I to dance next? Who are you?

question: I am the maid Marian.
answer: Then show yourself, child. For we knew each other well.

question: With the king away, these are lawless times. There are outlaws villainous enough to kidnap and ransom a relative of his.
answer: You know I am not one of them. Besides, I am sworn to protect you.

question: Protect me? Robin of Locksley was nothing but a spoiled bully.
answer: Allow that years of war and prison may change a man. Step forward, Marian, so I may see how you have changed. Er... the years have been kind.

question: Thank you. Now remove yourself from this household. A figure steps behind Robin. Sticks a sword in his back. As you can see, we are already well protected.
answer: Wait, Marian! ...ouch! You are truly courageous against an unarmed man. The figure gestures towards the door. Robin sidesteps. Slams an elbow. The sword drops. Slides across the floor. Robin moves for it, but the man intercepts, drawing a dagger. Robin darts to the wall. Rips off an antlered deer head. Defends himself as the attacker slashes at the horns. Marian. CUT TO:

question: Wait, Marian! ...ouch! You are truly courageous against an unarmed man. The figure gestures towards the door. Robin sidesteps. Slams an elbow. The sword drops. Slides across the floor. Robin moves for it, but the man intercepts, drawing a dagger. Robin darts to the wall. Rips off an antlered deer head. Defends himself as the attacker slashes at the horns. Marian. CUT TO:
answer: I trust Lord Locksley has recovered from his indisposition. Aslan laughs. Robin glares. Why would he wish me to be protected by the boy who burned my hair when I was a child?

question: We were together five terrible years in a Saracen prison.
answer: How do I know you didn't abandon him there to save your own skin. Robin hands her Peter's ring. She is shocked.

question: Marian, I'm sorry.
answer: I will forward your condolences to my mother. She turns her back. He searches for a way to reach her.

question: On my return, I found my father dead. The Sheriff denounced him as a Druid and took our lands.
answer: The people fear the Druids so much they'd believe anything. Nottingham would have me burned at the stake as a witch if he thought he could possess my property.

question: Why do you not join your mother in London? You would be safer there.
answer: I will not retreat. Besides, I have no interest in life at court. Gossip-mongering and currying favor. Here I am my own person.

question: The you must allow me to be your guardian.
answer: I do not need a guardian. She turns to face him. Streaming tears. My brother is dead. You cannot take his place. Robin grabs and holds her.

question: Marian, I don't want to replace him.
answer: What do you want? Their eyes meet... a sudden intimacy between them. Robin moves closer. Marian begins to respond, then pulls away. This is wrong. She runs back to the house. Robin stares after her. Aslan appears in the doorway with Duncan.

question: Soldiers coming here? Is this your protection?
answer: I killed some of the Sheriff's men. I fear I have placed you in danger.

question: I can take care of myself. There are horses in the stable. Go! Aslan runs into the stables.
answer: I'm not leaving. Marian ices him with a glare. Aslan reappears, with two bareback horses. Soldiers appear on the crest, led by Gisborne... With a mischievous grin, Marian runs to the soldiers.

question: Stop them! They're stealing my horses!
answer: Damn the girl! Aslan, can you ride? In answer, Aslan grins. Leaps onto a horse. With a single swift move he hoists Duncan up behind him and digs in his heels. The mare leaps forward, and over the estate wall. He can ride. He heads his horse at the wall. It stumbles. Barely clears it. Stones fly. Robin struggles to hold on. Marian stands directly in Gisborne's path.

question: Damn you, animal! Aslan shouts from the far bank.
answer: Treat it like a woman. Robin continues to hit his horse and hurl abuse. Closing in, the soldiers unfurl their crossbows. A flight of BOLTS WHISTLES ominously close to Robin. He must jump or die. Have you never had a woman? Gently, man. Soothe it!

question: Of course I've had a woman! Come on, pretty one. He pats the horse soothingly. The animal edges forward.
answer: Softly. With your knees.

question: I know! I know! The soldiers reload. Robin urges the horse at the steep drop. Easy, easy. Another wave of crossbow bolts. Robin launches the frightened animal into space. Hooves flail... touch down. Scramble up the other bank. Robin enthusiastically pats the horse's neck. I love you! The first two pursuers misjudge their leaps. Their mounts land sprawling in the riverbed.
answer: Robin of the Hood! Son of the devil worshipper.

question: What is your pleasure, Gisborne?
answer: It was I who strung your father's corpse to the castle gate. My pleasure will be in doing the same to you.

question: You survived one meeting. Our next will be your last.
answer: Your father died a coward, cursing your name and squealing like a stuck pig.

question: Be quiet! Listen. WIND GUSTS the trees in angry waves. Emits deathly SHRIEKS. The HORSES WHINNEY. Unnerved, Aslan smites around him with his scimitar. Wheels at the sounds, striking only air.
answer: Allah protect us from the evil spirits. Duncan clings to his back. Robin points.

question: Behind you! Aslan slashes out, futilely. No, there! And there! Aslan flails. Robin cracks up.
answer: Cease your mad laughing. I can feel them. Robin reaches into the branches. Pulls out a string of hollowed wooden tubes -- WINDCHIMES. Dozens of such strings on all the trees. He blows over the hollow end. A low chilling MOAN.

question: Here are your ghosts, Duncan. A child's toy put to good use. You scare easily, my painted Saladin. His laughter is broken by a piercing YELL. A red- jacketed figure swings down out of a tree on a rope. Catapults him to the ground. The bushes are instantly alive. Shaggy, wild-eyed men, armed with cudgels, scythes and hayforks. Twelfth- century Hell's Angels. The red-jacketed young turk, WILL SCARLET, leaps around Robin.
answer: Ring around the rosie!

question: Aslan! Aslan makes no move to intervene.
answer: Atishoo, Atishoo. We all fall down. Beg for mercy, rich man.

question: I beg of no man. Which of you scum has guts enough to face me man to man?
answer: What are ya, m'old cock?

question: Er... Robin... He pauses, checking the faces of the angry peasants. ...Hood. Robin Hood. Who are you?
answer: John Little. Bestman o' the woods.

question: Bestman? You lead this rabble?
answer: We waste time. Tax him.

question: Tax? For what?
answer: For passage through Sherwood.

question: I will pay no tax. Besides, I have nothing but my cloak and my sword.
answer: A man who travels with two servants and claims he's without money, is either a fool or a liar. Grabbing Robin, Little shakes him like a doll. Something CLINKS. Robin's father's medallion. Laughing heartily, Little rips it from Robin's neck and tosses it to Scarlet. And this one is a liar. Ahah! Gold! The men cheer. John snatches the medallion back from Will.

question: Your avenging army, my friend.
answer: That rabble?

question: All they need is a leader.
answer: They have a leader. A very large one.

question: Defeat him and they will follow you.
answer: Allah has taken your brains.

question: Allah has taken your brains.
answer: I hear the voice of a spoiled child, Master Robin. I suggest you cease your brave talk of revenge and flee to the north.

question: You, too? You expect me to fight that behemoth?
answer: Your father would expect you to act like a man. CUT TO:

question: Swimmin' time again, ol' chum. The coup de grace. Lands heavily. Robin teeters. Falls. Disappears under the foaming water... does not re-emerge. John waits. The spectators rush to the bank. No sign. Bloomin' shame. 'E were a brave 'un. Suddenly Robin arcs up out of the water. His hands clamp onto John's ankles. Robin heaves with all his might. John topples headfirst into the water. Surfaces in panic. Help! Cain't bloody swim. He submerges again. Robin pulls his head above water.
answer: Do you yield? Do you yield?

question: Yes!
answer: Good. Now put your feet down. John struggles, then his feet hit bottom... The water only reaches his chest.

question: I'll be buggered.
answer: Pay me the tax. A tense pause while all wait for Little's reaction.

question: Real honey. He takes the jug back. Sneezes royally, spewing all over the brew. Oblivious, he hands the contaminated jug to Aslan.
answer: With regrets, I decline.

question: An Englishman's mead not bleedin' good enough for ya?
answer: On the contrary. I thank you, but my faith prevents me from partaking in such enjoyments.

question: You owe me nothing, Wulf. I am glad I chanced by in time to help.
answer: C'mon, lad, drink! 'Twill put hair on your bloomin' chest. Wulf tries the brew. The impact is instant. He turns green and runs. His father cracks up.

question: Tell me about your men, John. John points to a short fellow with the build of a tree trunk.
answer: This stumpy one 'ere's David o' Doncaster. We calls 'im Bull.

question: How do you come by the name, Bull?
answer: 'Cuz o' my size, Sire.

question: Because you are short?
answer: Nay. 'Cuz I be so long.

question: No, Bull. Save it for the ladies. Drunken laughter. Robin turns to the next man at the fireside. Your name, friend? The man's bald pate blushes scarlet as he tries to respond, but he stutters too badly to get out a comprehensible word.
answer: That be Hal Brownwell, but the lads call i'm Hal Hiccup. The others make hiccup and belching sounds, and crack up at Hal's embarrassment. Hal strikes out angrily at his tormentors.

question: Hold! Hal, you have the face and hands of a farmer. I wager you are a strong and honest man, and I'd be glad to have you at my side in a fight. The next man who makes light of you will have to answer to me. There is murmuring around the group, but no one elects to try it. How is it there are so many of you in hiding?
answer: We're outlaws. Got prices on our 'eads, every man jack. Blasted Sheriff says we owes 'im taxes.

question: How do you fare?
answer: We get by, I reckon.

question: While the Sheriff steals your land and your families starve?
answer: What in bloody blazes'd ya have us do?

question: Your ghosts will only keep his men at bay so long, my friend. Soon the Sheriff will hunt you down and hang you. You must fight back.
answer: We show as much as a toe outside the forest, they'll slaughter us like bleedin' sheep.

question: We must organize. Win by guile.
answer: 'We'? Ya lookin' to join us, matie?

question: Stuff a flippin' cork in it, Will. The man's our guest. Will gets up. Angrily pushes his way out of the group. That there's Will Scarlet. Pay 'im no 'eed. 'E's full o' piss and wind.
answer: He is right to distrust me. I am a rich man's son. I have done no honest labor. But today I am as poor as any of you. Nottingham has stolen all that I own. And when I killed Gisborne's men, I, too, became an outlaw.

question: Ya're full o'bloody wind an' all, mate. This 'ere load o' rubbish agin the Sheriff's bloomin' army? Ya must be bloody jokin'.
answer: We can win. And I believe we will.

question: Too much mead, old friend. What day is it?
answer: Sunday, I believe.

question: Good. Do they still give alms to the poor at the mass?
answer: They do. These days the need for mercy is greater than ever.

question: Alms for a blind man. For one who cannot see your beauty.
answer: This is dangerous.

question: So you care for my safety?
answer: No, for mine. I do not wish to be seen with an outlaw.

question: Under the Sheriff's law, that's a badge of pride.
answer: He's put a price on your head.

question: How much?
answer: A hundred gold pieces.

question: Is that all? I have not annoyed him enough. Soon he will offer ten thousand.
answer: For ten thousand I would turn you in myself. Nottingham is mounting an army.

question: How do you know?
answer: He has rounded up every blacksmith in the county. He has them holed up in the castle making swords and armor.

question: What is he planning?
answer: I don't know, but there's no limit to the man's ambitions. Go!

question: If you need me, I will be with the woodsmen. Send for me as 'Robin Hood.'
answer: Robin! Do something for me.

question: What?
answer: Take a bath.

question: You shine like the sun, my lady. He raises her hand, as he did the girl's in the castle. Kisses it. You have been meeting with young Robin of Locksley. My cousin tells me the knave deprived you of some horses.
answer: Yes. A most disagreeable experience.

question: I deeply regret it, and I promise you he will be brought to justice. For subjecting you to such treatment, I will hang him from the walls with his own entrails. That gleam of insanity. Robin watches from a distance.
answer: I would like to see that, my lord. The Sheriff places his hand possessively on her shoulder.

question: My dear, a woman of your refinement is not safe living alone. If you would consent to bring your household within the city walls, I could give your needs my most personal attention.
answer: I thank you, Lord Nottingham, from the heart, but for now I prefer to stay in my family's ancestral home. My cousin, King Richard, will be deeply moved to hear of your concern for my welfare.

question: Alas, the King has many enemies both abroad and at home. I fear for his safe return.
answer: Fear not, my dear Sheriff. He will return. When he does, he will wish to reward his faithful subjects. The Sheriff smiles sourly and takes his leave. Marian deflates with relief. The Sheriff walks alone towards a side door.

question: A hundred crowns, Sheriff? You insult me. Nottingham starts to struggle. Robin draws blood. Remember young Robin of Locksley, Sheriff? Meet Robin Hood. Your nemesis. Your avenging angel.
answer: If you kill me, you will hang.

question: If I kill you, I will hang happy.
answer: What do you want?

question: I want to give you a chance. A chance you do not deserve. A chance to right your wrongs.
answer: I'm listening.

question: From this day forward you will cease to tax my people. You will renounce the charges against my father, and you will return his lands to me.
answer: Why should I?

question: Because for every harm you do, I swear by God I shall visit on you threefold in return.
answer: Empty words.

question: I am here with a blade at your throat. As long as I live, you will always know that I could be here again. A YELL from across the church. Gisborne has spotted them. Robin digs the knife a little deeper. Your answer?
answer: Never, fool.

question: A personal loan from the Sheriff.
answer: You should not have left without me, Englishman.

question: How so? You have not raised a finger to protect me.
answer: Before I had a choice.

question: It was my choice to do this alone.
answer: A foolish risk. If you had been killed, I would be cursed for eternity for failing to fulfil my pledge.

question: Then we shall take from him and his rich friends.
answer: Brave talk, Locksley. I say we take the rich boy in. Murmurs of general agreement.

question: Will, do you think the Sheriff will give everything back after I am gone?
answer: He will give us the reward, and our pardons.

question: Alright, Will. You can take me in on one condition. You must fight me. You may use the Sheriff's horse and arm yourself as you please. I will fight on foot. Unarmed.
answer: Unarmed?

question: If you lose, you will accept me as your leader. If you win, you may take me in. Dead or alive.
answer: Dead, Locksley. CUT TO:

question: I am grateful for your concern, friends, but I have to prove to them it is possible to overcome unequal odds. I am ready, Will. Will bends, as if checking the horse's legs. Secretly grabs a handful of sand. Swings into the saddle and digs in his heels. Closing in, Will flings the sand in Robin's eyes. Robin clutches his hands to his face, blinded. Will spins back to the attack. His sword slashes. Reacting to the sound, Robin rolls aside. The men cheer like a big fight crowd. Come on, you little piss pot. Do your worst! Will grabs a spear from a bystander. Robin stands his ground. Will lunges, Robin sidesteps. The horse is smarter than you are, Will. Some of the men laugh. Will is incensed. Robin ducks and weaves, easily evading Will's repeated charges. Robin ducks right under the horse's belly. Here, Will! You aim like a girl, Will! Will stabs wildly, more and more frustrated. Laughter spreads, as Robin plays hide and seek around the horse's legs. Grabbing the end of the spear, he clowns a tug of war. Enraged, Will strains and tries to kick Robin away. Suddenly, Robin lets go. Unbalanced, Will flies back- wards off his mount. Robin snatches the spear and raises it over his fallen adversary. The crowd falls silent. Robin strikes. The point quivers in the ground below Will's crotch. Will wriggles in terror. Impaled, his pants rip open. Thank the Lord you are not endowed like Bull.
answer: Bollocks, Will. Jus' bugger off, eh? Overpowered, Will relents. With a defiant glance, he skulks away. Ya got us by the short and curlies, Robin Hood. Now let's hear what ya got to bleedin' say.

question: Nottingham has taken from us everything we own. Now we are going to start taking from him.
answer: 'Ow in bloody blazes are we gonna do that?

question: We are going to tax him. DISSOLVE TO:
answer: Here they come.

question: How many?
answer: Two wagons. Twenty escort.

question: This treasure had a purpose. We must find out what. He turns at the sound of a brawl from the Friar's cart. The Friar is at the bottom of a struggling heap of bodies. Get off him. He's a man of the cloth. Robin drags the men off. The Friar clambers to his feet. Around him are strewn battered and winded woodsmen.
answer: The Lord's blessing on you, kind sir. These sinners were attempting to steal these libations destined for the monks of St. Catherine's. He indicates his cargo of barrels.

question: It appears to me, Reverend Friar, that many of the libations have found their way into your own esteemed person. Ignoring him, the Friar mounts the cart.
answer: A thousand pardons, sir, but duty beckons. I must hasten on.

question: My men are thirsty and have much to celebrate.
answer: Lord bless me, sir, are these your men? I had mistook them for common thieves. Kindly step aside.

question: Surely the Lord has the charity to spare a few barrels to good Christian men. The Friar relents, loosening his grip on the reins.
answer: Well, sir, if you wish them to share in the good Lord's brew... Casually reaching under the seat, he pulls out a club. Smites Robin with it. ... you must best me for it. Robin staggers. The Friar whips up the horse. Dazed, Robin grabs for the fat man's leg. Gets a holy sandal full in the face. Giddyup, nag! The Friar's horse, as obese as his driver, slowly raises his head from the grass and ambles forward. Robin runs after them and dives at the Friar, toppling him from the cart.

question: You leave when I say. Scrambling to his feet, the Friar glances skyward.
answer: Protect me, Lord. He sweeps his foot, knocking Robin's legs out from under him. Hurls his full body weight on top of him. Whooomf! Yield! He bounces on Robin's stomach. Robin can barely breathe. The woodsmen are enjoying the spectacle. Confess that Friar Tuck is a better, holier, and braver man than thou art, knave.

question: Never! Whoomf!
answer: Yield, I say! Yield to Friar Tuck. Desperate, Robin bites the Friar's leg. Tuck howls. Robin extricates himself, grabs for a weapon. Smashes the Friar's head with his drinking jug.

question: Yield yourself! He dives onto the Friar and hammers his head into the ground. Yield to Robin Hood. Tuck holds up a hand in surrender. Robin eases off.
answer: Thank you, Lord, for teaching me humility.

question: Well, Friar Tuck. We have need of an honest man of God, to minister to these men and their families. What do you say?
answer: I'd rather roast in hell. He punches Robin in the gut. CUT TO:

question: Giddyup, Friar. What do you say now, Tuck? Here are the meek of the earth. Tuck surveys the hopeful, hungry faces. The little hamlet of half-built huts. He folds his hands in a moment of prayer.
answer: The Lord moves in mysterious ways. I accept.

question: You will not regret it.
answer: Aye, but you may. CUT TO:

question: Spare your breath. I know nothing.
answer: I believe you. But this Arab here, he's got it into his barbarian brain that you know a whole lot more than nothing. And when he gets like this, he's very hard to reason with. With a hair-raising war cry, Aslan leaps INTO VIEW. Stripped to the waist, brandishing his scimitar. The Captain tries to back away. Robin tries to restrain Aslan, is hurled aside. Snarling, drooling at the mouth, Aslan explores the Captain's body with his hands. A butcher checking meat. I strongly advise you to talk. He hasn't eaten in weeks.

question: What does he want?
answer: You.

question: For Godsakes, get him off me!
answer: No, Aslan... not this one, Aslan. ... How about this other one?... Fatter, yes... more meat. The other soldier, who definitely has more flesh on the bone, is struck dumb with horror, as Aslan turns his attention to him. With one swing of his sword, Aslan slices through the man's ropes. Drags him to his feet. Little John runs over.

question: We were ambushed. In Sherwood Forest. Nottingham tests the sword against an anvil.
answer: Spanish steel, cousin. So much stronger than our native blades. Any losses?

question: All the men are gone.
answer: Yet again you are the sole survivor, cousin? Interesting. And the gold?

question: Well, it er... disappeared.
answer: Robin Hood?

question: They were woodsmen, dressed in green.
answer: Robin Hood. He places a hand reassuringly on his cousin's shoulder. Cousin, we must be strong. We cannot allow this outlaw to make fools of us. Without warning, he drives the blade into Gisborne's belly. And I cannot allow a lieutenant to fail me. It is indeed fine steel.

question: How dare you!
answer: Good morning, Lady Marian. In response, she starts pelting him with stones.

question: You send men to drag me from my home in the middle of the night, like some slave girl? Is this the way the famous Robin Hood treats a lady?
answer: Ah well... er, let me finish this bath you wished me to take. Then I'll explain.

question: I demand an explanation right now!
answer: If you will be patient, I could spare your propriety by...

question: I will decide when my propriety is compromised.
answer: As you wish.

question: This better be damned important. Robin leads her into a hut. Inside is a trove of cap- tured loot -- purses, jewelry, weaponry, fancy coats and... the treasure chest. At Robin's nod, Bull throws back the lid. Marian is speechless.
answer: Nottingham robs the poor. We rob Nottingham and give back to the poor.

question: Do you think he's going to let you get away with all this? The man is without mercy. He will annihilate you.
answer: Somebody has to take a stand.

question: You're taking a stand with the lives of these people. These young ones. A beat. She checks the faces. Her eyes meet Robin's. Is there a hint of concern for him also? What do you want from me?
answer: Nottingham was sending this gold to buy reinforcements from the Celtic tribesmen. We need to warn King Richard.

question: Nottingham would not dare challenge the King.
answer: The King is not in England to be challenged, is he? While he is away, he may lose his country. You are Richard's cousin. You can get word to him. He would believe you.

question: Now you want me to participate in your folly? A little girl approaches, holding a bouquet of wild flowers. Touched, Marian kneels to accept the offering. CUT TO:
answer: I am sending Duncan with you. Give him some warm food and a real bed. I grow tired of his bellyaching.

question: I'll think about it. It is a personal matter, my Lord, but one of vital importance.
answer: I understand, my dear lady. This is my most trusted emissary. He hands the letter to a solemn courier.

question: You will travel to France immediately. You must give this directly into the hands of the King, and him alone. The courier bows in acknowledgement. Marian indicates Sarah. My lady-in-waiting will accompany you. Surprised, the courier glances at the Bishop.
answer: My dear, I could not vouch for her safety. The journey is fraught with danger.

question: I appreciate your concern, my Lord, but Sarah is an accomplished rider. I must insist that she goes along.
answer: As you wish.

question: I am doing all I can. Aslan appears in the doorway, with Robin. Whips back the blanket. Fanny's chest is covered with black squirming creatures.
answer: By Allah, leeches! He starts to pull the parasites off. Tuck jumps at him.

question: Get away from her! Aslan pushes him away, continuing his work.
answer: Blood is like air. If she loses blood, she and the child will die. John is paralyzed with confusion. Tuck appeals to Robin.

question: He lies. He is the devil's seed, sent to lead us astray.
answer: Fool, both the Bible and the Koran instruct us to preserve life. Tuck raises an arm to strike Aslan. Robin blocks the blow. Aslan gently touches the mother's stomach. Your baby has not turned. It cannot be born without help.

question: What do you know, you damned savage?
answer: If you will allow me, I can help her. It will not be without danger.

question: Do not listen to him! He will kill her.
answer: If you do not listen to me, she will certainly die. And the child, too. Fanny cries out. John looks to Robin, pleading for advice.

question: Bring me a needle, thread, water, a skinning knife, and burning ashes. Wulf runs to obey. John looks horrified. Robin eases him outside, then returns to Aslan's side. They whisper.
answer: What are you going to do?

question: The child must be taken out by the knife.
answer: The knife?

question: I have seen it many times with horses.
answer: Horses? By the Lord, what are her chances?

question: After wasting so much blood... not good.
answer: Now you tell me! Wulf runs back in. Aslan holds up a piece of wood.

question: We will go there.
answer: No! You stay here, dammit! I will go alone.

question: You forget yourself. I am not your servant.
answer: Then be my friend. There are women and children here in greater need of your courage.

question: Marian!
answer: Death is not to be feared, Robin. Embrace it. Her LAUGH ECHOES around the cave, as if hundreds of lost souls are laughing with her. Robin crawls away, cover- ing his ears. Marian lifts his face to hers. Drink this. Weakly, Robin tries to push away the cup. Her hand grips his chin, forcing his mouth open. Drink. Look at me. Listen to me. You belong to me. Your soul is mine. You will obey my every word. Do you understand? Her face is inches from his. He tries to pull away, his subconscious sounding alarms.

question: Why, Marian?
answer: Because you love me. Say it. You love me. Say it!

question: I love you.
answer: Kiss me. He gives himself to her. Their lips meet... something changes in his vision. Her eyes glow red. Her face starts to shrivel -- He is kissing the wrinkled lips of Mortianna. He pulls away... strong arms grab him. He shakes his head, trying to make sense. Through his BLURRED vision, we see he is surrounded by masked men.

question: They have poisoned you. There are herbs that can alter a man's brain. I know of only one cure. He drops to one knee, slams Robin violently across the other. Slaps him on the back and forces his fingers down his throat. It worked for me this very morning. You will thank me for this later.
answer: You have fulfilled your vow. Now you can leave.

question: Your gratitude warms my heart.
answer: You ignored my request.

question: It is fortunate that I did.
answer: Because of you, another good man is dead.

question: He urged me to bring him. He was a brave man and I grieve for him. Praise be to Allah that I do not grieve for you also. Or for my broken vow.
answer: To hell with your damn vow.

question: I am glad you are feeling better. Ahead of them, Wulf shouts and reins in. He points into the distance. A huge cloud of smoke is darkening the sky.
answer: The forest! Ride!

question: Ya'll be jus' fine. Lil' smoke ain't gonna kill ya. Scared and injured woodsmen careen out of the trees. Full retreat.
answer: It's burning for miles, John. It's hotter than hades, and them damn screens ain't worth nothing. Two woodsmen, blinded and choking, stumble into one of their own camouflaged pits. Hideous screams as they're impaled on hidden stakes. John tries to gather the able- bodied men to his side.

question: 'Ere, lads... Over 'ere! We must make a stand. Most of them keep on running. Damn y'all! Ya're no more use than a load o' wet farts.
answer: Where's that damn Locksley? I'll swear he betrayed us.

question: My pride brought us to this.
answer: No, friend. It was you who gave these men pride.

question: I gave them nothing but false hope. Tomorrow we will disperse. These people can move south and start over. You must go home and win your Jasmina.
answer: And you?

question: I am no longer your responsibility.
answer: That is for me to decide.

question: Will! I thought you were taken.
answer: I was.

question: How did you escape?
answer: I promised to kill you.

question: Git us a rope, Hal, and we'll put the bleedin' weasel outa 'is misery.
answer: John, wait. Let us hear what he has to say.

question: No bugger 'scapes the Sheriff, 'nless 'e's linin' 'is bloomin' pockets.
answer: A traitor sneaks in and out under cover of darkness. Will walked in and announced himself.

question: You were to use this news to get close to me, and then kill me? Right, Will?
answer: Not straightway, of course.

question: What is your intention, Will?
answer: That depends on you, Locksley.

question: How so?
answer: I've never trusted you, that's no secret. What I wanna know is, are you gonna finish what you started? Will ya stay and keep us fightin' till every man jack of us is dead? Or will you run like the spoiled little rich boy I always took you for?

question: You present quite a choice. What would you have me do, Will?
answer: If you run, I will kill you.

question: Seven!
answer: What in blazes ya doin', woman? Where's the little 'uns?

question: Them's safe, wi' my mother. Robin, I been to town an' seen the scaffold and the guard towers.
answer: Ya gone bleedin' cracked, girl?

question: You go an' birth eight babies and then you can come an' tell me 'bout hurtin', ya big ox. I ain't gonna sit aroun' an' let one o' 'em die, neither.
answer: Ya should be bloody well mindin' the other seven. Tell 'er, Rob. Robin starts to draw a diagram on the ground with a stick.

question: When we are married, thirty of the northern barons will pledge me their support as king. As you predicted. Mortianna squats on the floor besides a platter of blood. Clasps the dice-like runes. What do you see in the portents? Mortianna rocks on her heels, clutching her taloned hands to her sides. She chants, fingering the bloody stones.
answer: The union. The blood of the lion and the house of Nottingham. New faith. New power. New souls. She stares at Nottingham, her red eyes demented. If there is no union, there will be darkness, despair, death. Ours!

question: Di not give me riddles, woman. We are to be married within hours. How can we be in danger?
answer: The blood does not lie.

question: Tell me how it will result.
answer: I have told you what I know.

question: Confound you, crone. Without my protection, the people would hunt you down, rip out your black heart and burn it.
answer: Without me, you are nothing. You are straw, a fleabite, a speck. Laugh, fool. I birthed you from this body. I stole a babe in this very castle, and killed it so that you might rise in its place. You are my son. Together we are strong. Now is not the time to doubt. Now is the time to believe, to be bold. The bold will prevail.

question: Sheriff! My Lord Sheriff! I have word for you! Of Robin Hood! Nottingham shouts to one of his mounted guards, who rides over, grabs Will by the collar, and drags him to his side.
answer: Ah, the turncoat. Did you succeed?

question: I found his lair, but alas he still lives. The Sheriff strikes down with his armored hand. Will crumples.
answer: Stretch his neck with the others. Hands yank Will to his feet. Dazed, he tries to speak. Disinterested, Nottingham turns away, until he catches...

question: ...He... He... is here!
answer: Locksley, here? Where ? Will struggles to get free of his holders.

question: Call off your dogs.
answer: Release him!... Now, where is he?

question: I want your word, in front of these witnesses. If I tell you, I will go free.
answer: We will find him.

question: He is concealed. He is going to free the prisoners and stop the wedding. Nottingham's jaw tightens. Eyes the prisoners, the scaffold.
answer: Put Hood in my hands, you go free.

question: With the reward. Ten thousand crowns.
answer: Damn your worthless hide! Just tell me where he is.

question: The reward! The parade of prisoners reaches them. Seeing Will, Wulf charges at him, screaming in blind rage. Soldiers grab Wulf. Throw him down, kicking and beating. Voices in the crowd plead to let him be. Someone tries to intervene, gets hurled down.
answer: You'll get your reward. Where is he? CUT TO:

question: Step down, friar.
answer: As you wish, sire. Is there something amiss?

question: This man claims you have outlaws concealed in these barrels. Among them the cursed Robin Hood. Tuck glares at Will with unconcealed hatred.
answer: This man will rot in hell as a knave and a liar. These are libations for the celebration of your lordship's nuptials.

question: Break one open!
answer: Why waste fine vintage, my lord? A cask is shattered... wine torrents out.

question: I'm going home the easy way, Robin.
answer: You die on me, you son of satan, and I swear I'll bury you as a Christian in St. Catherine's Cathedral with a thousand monks chanting prayers for your miserable soul. You hear me?

question: I have no strength, Brother Tuck.
answer: A fine friend you are! By the grace of Allah and Jehovah we have won the day, and you want to give up the ghost. I'll pickle your remains in mead, lay you in your grave with a pig for a companion, and mark it with a cross as big as this castle.

question: Please! It hurts when I laugh.
answer: See. There's life in the heathen dog yet.
